13.verse: Thus the priest shall make atonement for the sin that the man committed in any of the above cases, and it will be forgiven. The rest of the flour, like the cereal offerings, shall belong to the priest."

14.verse: The LORD said to Moses,

15.verse: "If someone commits a sin by inadvertently cheating in the LORD'S sacred dues, he shall bring to the LORD as his guilt offering an unblemished ram from the flock, valued at two silver shekels according to the standard of the sanctuary shekel.

16.verse: He shall also restore what he has sinfully withheld from the sanctuary, adding to it a fifth of its value. This is to be given to the priest, who shall then make atonement for him with the guilt-offering ram, and he will be forgiven.

17.verse: "If someone, without being aware of it, commits such a sin by doing one of the things which are forbidden by some commandment of the LORD, that he incurs guilt for which he must answer,

18.verse: he shall bring as a guilt offering to the priest an unblemished ram of the flock of the established value. The priest shall then make atonement for the fault which was unwittingly committed, and it will be forgiven.

19.verse: Such is the offering for guilt; the penalty of the guilt must be paid to the LORD."

20.verse: The LORD said to Moses,

21.verse: "If someone commits a sin of dishonesty against the LORD by denying his neighbor a deposit or a pledge for a stolen article, or by otherwise retaining his neighbor's goods unjustly,

22.verse: or if, having found a lost article, he denies the fact and swears falsely about it with any of the sinful oaths that men make in such cases,

23.verse: he shall therefore, since he has incurred guilt by his sin, restore the thing that was stolen or unjustly retained by him or the deposit left with him or the lost article he found

24.verse: or whatever else he swore falsely about; on the day of his guilt offering he shall make full restitution of the thing itself, and in addition, give the owner one fifth of its value.

25.verse: As his guilt offering he shall bring to the LORD an unblemished ram of the flock of the established value. When he has presented this as his guilt offering to the priest,

26.verse: the latter shall make atonement for him before the LORD, and he will be forgiven whatever guilt he may have incurred."

annotations.1: [15] Cheating: not offering the full amount in tithes, first fruits, etc. Guilt offering: its characteristic was a certain additional penalty imposed as reparation for the injustice involved in the fault which was atoned for by this sacrifice. However, in certain passages, e.g., Lev 14:12- 13; Numbers 6:12; Ezra 10:19, the term "guilt offering" is used for more important cases of "sin offerings" where no apparent injustice is involved
annotations.2: [17] Without being aware of it: the case naturally presupposes that later on the offender learns of his mistake. Cf Lev 4:13, 14.

1.verse: The LORD said to Moses,

2.verse: "This is the law for the victim of leprosy at the time of his purification. He shall be brought to the priest,

3.verse: who is to go outside the camp to examine him. If the priest finds that the sore of leprosy has healed in the leper,

4.verse: he shall order the man who is to be purified, to get two live, clean birds, as well as some cedar wood, scarlet yarn, and hyssop.

5.verse: The priest shall then order him to slay one of the birds over an earthen vessel with spring water in it.

6.verse: Taking the living bird with the cedar wood, the scarlet yarn and the hyssop, the priest shall dip them all in the blood of the bird that was slain over the spring water,

7.verse: and then sprinkle seven times the man to be purified from his leprosy. When he has thus purified him, he shall let the living bird fly away over the countryside.

8.verse: The man being purified shall then wash his garments and shave off all his hair and bathe in water; only when he is thus made clean may he come inside the camp; but he shall still remain outside his tent for seven days.

9.verse: On the seventh day he shall again shave off all the hair of his head, his beard, his eyebrows, and any other hair he may have, and also wash his garments and bathe his body in water; and so he will be clean.

10.verse: "On the eighth day he shall take two unblemished male lambs, one unblemished yearling ewe lamb, three tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil for a cereal offering, and one log of oil.

11.verse: The priest who performs the purification ceremony shall place the man who is being purified, as well as all these offerings, before the LORD at the entrance of the meeting tent.

12.verse: Taking one of the male lambs, the priest shall present it as a guilt offering, along with the log of oil, waving them as a wave offering before the LORD.

13.verse: (This lamb he shall slaughter in the sacred place where the sin offering and the holocaust are slaughtered; because, like the sin offering, the guilt offering belongs to the priest and is most sacred.)

14.verse: Then the priest shall take some of the blood of the guilt offering and put it on the tip of the man's right ear, the thumb of his right hand, and the big toe of his right foot.

15.verse: The priest shall also take the log of oil and pour some of it into the palm of his own left hand;

16.verse: then, dipping his right forefinger in it, he shall sprinkle it seven times before the LORD.

17.verse: Of the oil left in his hand the priest shall put some on the tip of the man's right ear, the thumb of his right hand, and the big toe of his right foot, over the blood of the guilt offering.

18.verse: The rest of the oil in his hand the priest shall put on the head of the man being purified. Thus shall the priest make atonement for him before the LORD.

19.verse: Only after he has offered the sin offering in atonement for the man's uncleanness shall the priest slaughter the holocaust

20.verse: and offer it, together with the cereal offering, on the altar before the LORD. When the priest has thus made atonement for him, the man will be clean.

21.verse: "If a man is poor and cannot afford so much, he shall take one male lamb for a guilt offering, to be used as a wave offering in atonement for himself, one tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil for a cereal offering, a log of oil,

22.verse: and two turtledoves or pigeons, which he can more easily afford, the one as a sin offering and the other as a holocaust.

23.verse: On the eighth day of his purification he shall bring them to the priest, at the entrance of the meeting tent before the LORD.

24.verse: Taking the guilt-offering lamb, along with the log of oil, the priest shall wave them as a wave offering before the LORD.

25.verse: When he has slaughtered the guilt-offering lamb, he shall take some of its blood, and put it on the tip of the right ear of the man being purified, on the thumb of his right hand, and on the big toe of his right foot.

26.verse: The priest shall then pour some of the oil into the palm of his own left hand

27.verse: and with his right forefinger sprinkle it seven times before the LORD.

28.verse: Some of the oil in his hand the priest shall also put on the tip of the man's right ear, the thumb of his right hand, and the big toe of his right foot, over the blood of the guilt offering.

29.verse: The rest of the oil in his hand the priest shall put on the man's head. Thus shall he make atonement for him before the LORD.

30.verse: Then, of the turtledoves or pigeons, such as the man can afford,

31.verse: the priest shall offer up one as a sin offering and the other as a holocaust, along with the cereal offering. Thus shall the priest make atonement before the LORD for the man who is to be purified.

32.verse: This is the law for one afflicted with leprosy who has insufficient means for his purification."

33.verse: The LORD said to Moses and Aaron,

34.verse: "When you come into the land of Canaan, which I am giving you to possess, if I put a leprous infection on any house of the land you occupy,

35.verse: the owner of the house shall come and report to the priest, 'It looks to me as if my house were infected.'

36.verse: The priest shall then order the house to be cleared out before he goes in to examine the infection, lest everything in the house become unclean. Only after this is he to go in to examine the house.

37.verse: If the priest, on examining it, finds that the infection on the walls of the house consists of greenish or reddish depressions which seem to go deeper than the surface of the wall,

38.verse: he shall close the door of the house behind him and quarantine the house for seven days.

39.verse: On the seventh day the priest shall return to examine the house again. If he finds that the infection has spread on the walls,

40.verse: he shall order the infected stones to be pulled out and cast in an unclean place outside the city.

41.verse: The whole inside of the house shall then be scraped, and the mortar that has been scraped off shall be dumped in an unclean place outside the city.

42.verse: Then new stones shall be brought and put in the place of the old stones, and new mortar shall be made and plastered on the house.

43.verse: "If the infection breaks out once more after the stones have been pulled out and the house has been scraped and replastered,

44.verse: the priest shall come again; and if he finds that the infection has spread in the house, it is corrosive leprosy, and the house is unclean.

45.verse: It shall be pulled down, and all its stones, beams and mortar shall be hauled away to an unclean place outside the city.

46.verse: Whoever enters a house while it is quarantined shall be unclean until evening.

47.verse: Whoever sleeps or eats in such a house shall also wash his garments.

48.verse: If the priest finds, when he comes to examine the house, that the infection has in fact not spread after the plastering, he shall declare the house clean, since the infection has been healed.

49.verse: To purify the house, he shall take two birds, as well as cedar wood, scarlet yarn, and hyssop.

50.verse: One of the birds he shall slay over an earthen vessel with spring water in it.

51.verse: Then, taking the cedar wood, the hyssop and the scarlet yarn, together with the living bird, he shall dip them all in the blood of the slain bird and the spring water, and sprinkle the house seven times.

52.verse: Thus shall he purify the house with the bird's blood and the spring water, along with the living bird, the cedar wood, the hyssop, and the scarlet yarn.

53.verse: He shall then let the living bird fly away over the countryside outside the city. When he has thus made atonement for it, the house will be clean.

54.verse: "This is the law for every kind of human leprosy and scall,

55.verse: for leprosy of garments and houses,

56.verse: as well as for scabs, pustules and blotches,

57.verse: so that it may be manifest when there is a state of uncleanness and when a state of cleanness. This is the law for leprosy."

annotations.1: [4] Scarlet yarn: probably used for tying the hyssop sprig to the cedar branchlet
annotations.2: [5] Spring water: literally, "living water," taken from some source of running water, not from a cistern
annotations.3: [22] Two turtledoves: substitutes for the two additional lambs, similar to the offering of a poor woman after childbirth. Cf Lev 12:8.

1.verse: The LORD said to Moses and Aaron,

2.verse: "Speak to the Israelites and tell them: Of all land animals these are the ones you may eat:

3.verse: any animal that has hoofs you may eat, provided it is cloven-footed and chews the cud.

4.verse: But you shall not eat any of the following that only chew the cud or only have hoofs: the camel, which indeed chews the cud, but does not have hoofs and is therefore unclean for you;

5.verse: the rock badger, which indeed chews the cud, but does not have hoofs and is therefore unclean for you;

6.verse: the hare, which indeed chews the cud, but does not have hoofs and is therefore unclean for you; and the pig,

7.verse: which does indeed have hoofs and is cloven-footed, but does not chew the cud and is therefore unclean for you.

8.verse: Their flesh you shall not eat, and their dead bodies you shall not touch; they are unclean for you.

9.verse: "Of the various creatures that live in the water, you may eat the following: whatever in the seas or in river waters has both fins and scales you may eat.

10.verse: But of the various creatures that crawl or swim in the water, whether in the sea or in the rivers, all those that lack either fins or scales are loathsome for you,

11.verse: and you shall treat them as loathsome. Their flesh you shall not eat, and their dead bodies you shall loathe.

12.verse: Every water creature that lacks fins or scales is loathsome for you.

13.verse: "Of the birds, these you shall loathe and, as loathsome, they shall not be eaten: the eagle, the vulture, the osprey,

14.verse: the kite, the various species of falcons,

15.verse: the various species of crows,

16.verse: the ostrich, the nightjar, the gull, the various species of hawks,

17.verse: the owl, the cormorant, the screech owl,

18.verse: the barn owl, the desert owl, the buzzard,

19.verse: the stork, the various species of herons, the hoopoe, and the bat.

20.verse: "The various winged insects that walk on all fours are loathsome for you.

21.verse: But of the various winged insects that walk on all fours you may eat those that have jointed legs for leaping on the ground;

22.verse: hence of these you may eat the following: the various kinds of locusts, the various kinds of grasshoppers, the various kinds of katydids, and the various kinds of crickets.

23.verse: All other winged insects that have four legs are loathsome for you.

24.verse: "Such is the uncleanness that you contract, that everyone who touches their dead bodies shall be unclean until evening,

25.verse: and everyone who picks up any part of their dead bodies shall wash his garments and be unclean until evening.

26.verse: All hoofed animals that are not cloven-footed or do not chew the cud are unclean for you; everyone who touches them becomes unclean.

27.verse: Of the various quadrupeds, all those that walk on paws are unclean for you; everyone who touches their dead bodies shall be unclean until evening,

28.verse: and everyone who picks up their dead bodies shall wash his garments and be unclean until evening. Such is their uncleanness for you.

29.verse: "Of the creatures that swarm on the ground, the following are unclean for you: the rat, the mouse, the various kinds of lizards,

30.verse: the gecko, the chameleon, the agama, the skink, and the mole.

31.verse: Among the various swarming creatures, these are unclean for you. Everyone who touches them when they are dead shall be unclean until evening.

32.verse: Everything on which one of them falls when dead becomes unclean. Any such article that men use, whether it be an article of wood, cloth, leather or goat hair, must be put in water and remain unclean until evening, when it again becomes clean.

33.verse: Should any of these creatures fall into a clay vessel, everything in it becomes unclean, and the vessel itself you must break.

34.verse: Any solid food that was in contact with water, and any liquid that men drink, in any such vessel become unclean.

35.verse: Any object on which one of their dead bodies falls, becomes unclean; if it is an oven or a jar-stand, this must be broken to pieces; they are unclean and shall be treated as unclean by you.

36.verse: However, a spring or a cistern for collecting water remains clean; but whoever touches the dead body becomes unclean.

37.verse: Any sort of cultivated grain remains clean even though one of their dead bodies falls on it;

38.verse: but if the grain has become moistened, it becomes unclean when one of these falls on it.

39.verse: "When one of the animals that you could otherwise eat, dies of itself, anyone who touches its dead body shall be unclean until evening;

40.verse: and anyone who eats of its dead body shall wash his garments and be unclean until evening; so also, anyone who removes its dead body shall wash his garments and be unclean until evening.

41.verse: "All the creatures that swarm on the ground are loathsome and shall not be eaten.

42.verse: Whether it crawls on its belly, goes on all fours, or has many legs, you shall eat no swarming creature: they are loathsome.

43.verse: Do not make yourselves loathsome or unclean with any swarming creature through being contaminated by them.

44.verse: For I, the LORD, am your God; and you shall make and keep yourselves holy, because I am holy. You shall not make yourselves unclean, then, by any swarming creature that crawls on the ground.

45.verse: Since I, the LORD, brought you up from the land of Egypt that I might be your God, you shall be holy, because I am holy.

46.verse: "This is the law for animals and birds and for all the creatures that move about in the water or swarm on the ground,

47.verse: that you may distinguish between the clean and the unclean, between creatures that may be eaten and those that may not be eaten."

annotations.1: [1-3] These distinctions between edible and inedible meats were probably based on traditional ideas of hygiene, but they are here given a moral, religious basis: the inedible varieties are classified as "unclean" to remind the Israelites that they are to be a pure and holy people, dedicated to the Lord
annotations.2: [5-6] According to modern zoology, the rock badger (hyrax Syriacus) is classified as an ungulate, and the hare as a rodent; neither is a ruminant. They appear to chew their food as the true ruminants do, and it is upon this appearance that the classification in the text is based
annotations.3: [13-19, 30] The identification of the various Hebrew names for these birds and reptiles is in many cases uncertain
annotations.4: [19] The bat: actually a mammal, but listed here with the birds because of its wings
annotations.5: [22] The Hebrew distinguishes four classes of edible locust-like insects, but the difference between them is quite uncertain. Cf Matthew 3:4
annotations.6: [24-28] This paragraph sharpens the prohibition against unclean animals: not only is their meat unfit for food, but contact with their dead bodies makes a person ritually unclean
annotations.7: [26] All hoofed animals that are not cloven-footed: such as the horse and the ass
annotations.8: [27] All those that walk on paws: such as dogs and cats
annotations.9: [36] Whoever touches the dead body: to remove the dead insect from the water supply.

1.verse: The LORD said to Moses,

2.verse: "Speak to the Israelites and tell them: When anyone fulfills a vow of offering one or more persons to the LORD, who are to be ransomed at a fixed sum of money,

3.verse: for persons between the ages of twenty and sixty, the fixed sum, in sanctuary shekels, shall be fifty silver shekels for a man,

4.verse: and thirty shekels for a woman;

5.verse: for persons between the ages of five and twenty, the fixed sum shall be twenty shekels for a youth, and ten for a maiden;

6.verse: for persons between the ages of one month and five years, the fixed sum shall be five silver shekels for a boy, and three for a girl;

7.verse: for persons of sixty or more, the fixed sum shall be fifteen shekels for a man, and ten for a woman.

8.verse: However, if the one who took the vow is too poor to meet the fixed sum, the person must be set before the priest, who shall determine the sum for his ransom in keeping with the means of the one who made the vow.

9.verse: "If the offering vowed to the LORD is an animal that may be sacrificed, every such animal, when vowed to the LORD, becomes sacred.

10.verse: The offerer shall not present a substitute for it by exchanging either a better for a worse one or a worse for a better one. If he attempts to offer one animal in place of another, both the original and its substitute shall be treated as sacred.

11.verse: If the animal vowed to the LORD is unclean and therefore unfit for sacrifice, it must be set before the priest,

12.verse: who shall determine its value in keeping with its good or bad qualities, and the value set by the priest shall stand.

13.verse: If the offerer wishes to redeem the animal, he shall pay one fifth more than this valuation.

14.verse: "When someone dedicates his house as sacred to the LORD, the priest shall determine its value in keeping with its good or bad points, and the value set by the priest shall stand.

15.verse: If the one who dedicated his house wishes to redeem it, he shall pay one fifth more than the price thus established, and then it will again be his.

16.verse: "If the object which someone dedicates to the LORD is a piece of his hereditary land, its valuation shall be made according to the amount of seed required to sow it, the acreage sown with a homer of barley seed being valued at fifty silver shekels.

17.verse: If the dedication of a field is made at the beginning of a jubilee period, the full valuation shall hold;

18.verse: but if it is some time after this, the priest shall estimate its money value according to the number of years left until the next jubilee year, with a corresponding rebate on the valuation.

19.verse: If the one who dedicated his field wishes to redeem it, he shall pay one fifth more than the price thus established, and so reclaim it.

20.verse: If, instead of redeeming such a field, he sells it to someone else, it may no longer be redeemed;

21.verse: but at the jubilee it shall be released as sacred to the LORD; like a field that is doomed, it shall become priestly property.

22.verse: "If the field that some man dedicates to the LORD is one he had purchased and not a part of his hereditary property,

23.verse: the priest shall compute its value in proportion to the number of years until the next jubilee, and on the same day the price thus established shall be given as sacred to the LORD;

24.verse: at the jubilee, however, the field shall revert to the hereditary owner of this land from whom it had been purchased.

25.verse: "Every valuation shall be made according to the standard of the sanctuary shekel. There are twenty gerahs to the shekel.

26.verse: "Note that a first-born animal, which as such already belongs to the LORD, may not be dedicated by vow to him. If it is an ox or a sheep, it shall be ceded to the LORD;

27.verse: but if it is an unclean animal, it may be redeemed by paying one fifth more than its fixed value. If it is not redeemed, it shall be sold at its fixed value.

28.verse: "Note, also, that any one of his possessions which a man vows as doomed to the LORD, whether it is a human being or an animal or a hereditary field, shall be neither sold nor ransomed; everything that is thus doomed becomes most sacred to the LORD.

29.verse: All human beings that are doomed lose the right to be redeemed; they must be put to death.

30.verse: "All tithes of the land, whether in grain from the fields or in fruit from the trees, belong to the LORD, as sacred to him.

31.verse: If someone wishes to buy back any of his tithes, he shall pay one fifth more than their value.

32.verse: The tithes of the herd and the flock shall be determined by ceding to the LORD as sacred every tenth animal as they are counted by the herdsman's rod.

33.verse: It shall not matter whether good ones or bad ones are thus chosen, and no exchange may be made. If any exchange is attempted, both the original animal and its substitute shall be treated as sacred, without the right of being bought back."

34.verse: These are the commandments which the LORD gave Moses on Mount Sinai for the Israelites.

annotations.1: [12] Determine its value: fix the price at which the animal may be sold to someone else. Only the original owner must pay the twenty percent tax, as a penalty for buying back what he had vowed to God. So also for houses and fields that are vowed to the Lord, as treated of in the following verses. The money from the sale or from the redemption of such vowed property naturally goes to the sanctuary
annotations.2: [27] An unclean animal: such as the first-born of an ass, which was unfit for sacrifice. According to Exodus 13:13; 34:20, a first-born ass was to be redeemed by offering a sheep in its stead, or was to have its neck broken. The present law is probably a later modification of the earlier one
annotations.3: [29] All human beings that are doomed: according to some interpreters, this signifies the idolatrous Canaanites, who were doomed to destruction by divine authority; according to others, this drastic law was enacted for the purpose of discouraging private persons from rashly vowing their slaves or other dependents as offerings to God. Cf Exodus 22:19; Deut 13:13-19.

1.verse: After the death of Aaron's two sons, who died when they approached the LORD'S presence, the LORD spoke to Moses

2.verse: and said to him, "Tell your brother Aaron that he is not to come whenever he pleases into the sanctuary, inside the veil, in front of the propitiatory on the ark; otherwise, when I reveal myself in a cloud above the propitiatory, he will die.

3.verse: Only in this way may Aaron enter the sanctuary. He shall bring a young bullock for a sin offering and a ram for a holocaust.

4.verse: He shall wear the sacred linen tunic, with the linen drawers next his flesh, gird himself with the linen sash and put on the linen miter. But since these vestments are sacred, he shall not put them on until he has first bathed his body in water.

5.verse: From the Israelite community he shall receive two male goats for a sin offering and one ram for a holocaust.

6.verse: "Aaron shall bring in the bullock, his sin offering to atone for himself and for his household.

7.verse: Taking the two male goats and setting them before the LORD at the entrance of the meeting tent,

8.verse: he shall cast lots to determine which one is for the LORD and which for Azazel.

9.verse: The goat that is determined by lot for the LORD, Aaron shall bring in and offer up as a sin offering.

10.verse: But the goat determined by lot for Azazel he shall set alive before the LORD, so that with it he may make atonement by sending it off to Azazel in the desert.

11.verse: "Thus shall Aaron offer up the bullock, his sin offering, to atone for himself and for his family. When he has slaughtered it,

12.verse: he shall take a censer full of glowing embers from the altar before the LORD, as well as a double handful of finely ground fragrant incense, and bringing them inside the veil,

13.verse: there before the LORD he shall put incense on the fire, so that a cloud of incense may cover the propitiatory over the commandments; else he will die.

14.verse: Taking some of the bullock's blood, he shall sprinkle it with his finger on the fore part of the propitiatory and likewise sprinkle some of the blood with his finger seven times in front of the propitiatory.

15.verse: "Then he shall slaughter the people's sin-offering goat, and bringing its blood inside the veil, he shall do with it as he did with the bullock's blood, sprinkling it on the propitiatory and before it.

16.verse: Thus he shall make atonement for the sanctuary because of all the sinful defilements and faults of the Israelites. He shall do the same for the meeting tent, which is set up among them in the midst of their uncleanness.

17.verse: No one else may be in the meeting tent from the time he enters the sanctuary to make atonement until he departs. When he has made atonement for himself and his household, as well as for the whole Israelite community,

18.verse: he shall come out to the altar before the LORD and make atonement for it also. Taking some of the bullock's and the goat's blood, he shall put it on the horns around the altar,

19.verse: and with his finger sprinkle some of the blood on it seven times. Thus he shall render it clean and holy, purged of the defilements of the Israelites.

20.verse: "When he has completed the atonement rite for the sanctuary, the meeting tent and the altar, Aaron shall bring forward the live goat.

21.verse: Laying both hands on its head, he shall confess over it all the sinful faults and transgressions of the Israelites, and so put them on the goat's head. He shall then have it led into the desert by an attendant.

22.verse: Since the goat is to carry off their iniquities to an isolated region, it must be sent away into the desert.

23.verse: "After Aaron has again gone into the meeting tent, he shall strip off and leave in the sanctuary the linen vestments he had put on when he entered there.

24.verse: After bathing his body with water in a sacred place, he shall put on his vestments, and then come out and offer his own and the people's holocaust, in atonement for himself and for the people,

25.verse: and also burn the fat of the sin offering on the altar.

26.verse: "The man who has led away the goat for Azazel shall wash his garments and bathe his body in water; only then may he enter the camp.

27.verse: The sin-offering bullock and goat whose blood was brought into the sanctuary to make atonement, shall be taken outside the camp, where their hides and flesh and offal shall be burned up in the fire.

28.verse: The one who burns them shall wash his garments and bathe his body in water; only then may he enter the camp.

29.verse: "This shall be an everlasting ordinance for you: on the tenth day of the seventh month every one of you, whether a native or a resident alien, shall mortify himself and shall do no work.

30.verse: Since on this day atonement is made for you to make you clean, so that you may be cleansed of all your sins before the LORD,

31.verse: by everlasting ordinance it shall be a most solemn sabbath for you, on which you must mortify yourselves.

32.verse: "This atonement is to be made by the priest who has been anointed and ordained to the priesthood in succession to his father. He shall wear the linen garments, the sacred vestments,

33.verse: and make atonement for the sacred sanctuary, the meeting tent and the altar, as well as for the priests and all the people of the community.

34.verse: This, then, shall be an everlasting ordinance for you: once a year atonement shall be made for all the sins of the Israelites." Thus was it done, as the LORD had commanded Moses.

annotations.1: [2] The sanctuary, inside the veil: the innermost part of the sanctuary, known also as "the holy of holies." Cf Exodus 26:33-34. Here the high priest was allowed to enter only once a year, on Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement. In Hebrews 9:3-12 this ceremony is applied to Christ's single act of Redemption, whereby he won for us an everlasting atonement. Propitiatory: see note on Exodus 25:17
annotations.2: Azazel: perhaps a name for Satan, used only in this chapter. The ancient versions translated this word as "the escaping goat," whence the English word "scapegoat."
annotations.3: [13] Else he will die: the smoke is to conceal the resplendent majesty of God, the sight of which would strike any man dead
annotations.4: [23] This verse is best read after Lev 16:25. According to later Jewish practice the high priest again went into the holy of holies to remove the censer
annotations.5: [29] Mortify himself: literally, "afflict his soul"; traditionally understood by the Jews as signifying abstinence from all food. This is the only fast day prescribed in the Mosaic law.

1.verse: The LORD said to Moses,

2.verse: "Speak to the whole Israelite community and tell them: Be holy, for I, the LORD your God, am holy.

3.verse: Revere your mother and father, and keep my sabbaths. I, the LORD, am your God.

4.verse: "Do not turn aside to idols, nor make molten gods for yourselves. I, the LORD, am your God.

5.verse: "When you sacrifice your peace offering to the LORD, if you wish it to be acceptable,

6.verse: it must be eaten on the very day of your sacrifice or on the following day. Whatever is left over until the third day shall be burned up in the fire.

7.verse: If any of it is eaten on the third day, the sacrifice will be unacceptable as refuse;

8.verse: whoever eats of it then shall pay the penalty for having profaned what is sacred to the LORD. Such a one shall be cut off from his people.

9.verse: "When you reap the harvest of your land, you shall not be so thorough that you reap the field to its very edge, nor shall you glean the stray ears of grain.

10.verse: Likewise, you shall not pick your vineyard bare, nor gather up the grapes that have fallen. These things you shall leave for the poor and the alien. I, the LORD, am your God.

11.verse: "You shall not steal. You shall not lie or speak falsely to one another.

12.verse: You shall not swear falsely by my name, thus profaning the name of your God. I am the LORD.

13.verse: "You shall not defraud or rob your neighbor. You shall not withhold overnight the wages of your day laborer.

14.verse: You shall not curse the deaf, or put a stumbling block in front of the blind, but you shall fear your God. I am the LORD.

15.verse: "You shall not act dishonestly in rendering judgment. Show neither partiality to the weak nor deference to the mighty, but judge your fellow men justly.

16.verse: You shall not go about spreading slander among your kinsmen; nor shall you stand by idly when your neighbor's life is at stake. I am the LORD.

17.verse: "You shall not bear hatred for your brother in your heart. Though you may have to reprove your fellow man, do not incur sin because of him.

18.verse: Take no revenge and cherish no grudge against your fellow countrymen. You shall love your neighbor as yourself. I am the LORD.

19.verse: "Keep my statutes: do not breed any of your domestic animals with others of a different species; do not sow a field of yours with two different kinds of seed; and do not put on a garment woven with two different kinds of thread.

20.verse: "If a man has carnal relations with a female slave who has already been living with another man but has not yet been redeemed or given her freedom, they shall be punished but not put to death, because she is not free.

21.verse: The man, moreover, shall bring to the entrance of the meeting tent a ram as his guilt offering to the LORD.

22.verse: With this ram the priest shall make atonement before the LORD for the sin he has committed, and it will be forgiven him.

23.verse: "When you come into the land and plant any fruit tree there, first look upon its fruit as if it were uncircumcised. For three years, while its fruit remains uncircumcised, it may not be eaten.

24.verse: In the fourth year, however, all of its fruit shall be sacred to the LORD as a thanksgiving feast to him.

25.verse: Not until the fifth year may you eat its fruit. Thus it will continue its yield for you. I, the LORD, am your God.

26.verse: "Do not eat meat with the blood still in it. Do not practice divination or soothsaying.

27.verse: Do not clip your hair at the temples, nor trim the edges of your beard.

28.verse: Do not lacerate your bodies for the dead, and do not tattoo yourselves. I am the LORD.

29.verse: "You shall not degrade your daughter by making a prostitute of her; else the land will become corrupt and full of lewdness.

30.verse: Keep my sabbaths, and reverence my sanctuary. I am the LORD.

31.verse: "Do not go to mediums or consult fortune-tellers, for you will be defiled by them. I, the LORD, am your God.

32.verse: "Stand up in the presence of the aged, and show respect for the old; thus shall you fear your God. I am the LORD.

33.verse: "When an alien resides with you in your land, do not molest him.

34.verse: You shall treat the alien who resides with you no differently than the natives born among you; have the same love for him as for yourself; for you too were once aliens in the land of Egypt. I, the LORD, am your God.

35.verse: "Do not act dishonestly in using measures of length or weight or capacity.

36.verse: You shall have a true scale and true weights, an honest ephah and an honest hin. I, the LORD, am your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt.

37.verse: Be careful, then, to observe all my statutes and decrees. I am the LORD."

annotations.1: [18] You shall love your neighbor as yourself: cited by our Lord as the second of the two most important commandments of God. Cf Matthew 22:39; Mark 12:31. Although in the present context the word "neighbor" is restricted to "fellow countrymen," in Luke 10:29-37 Christ extends its meaning to embrace all men, even enemies. Cf also Matthew 5:43-45
annotations.2: [20-22] This law seems out of its proper context here; perhaps it stood originally after Lev 20:12. Female slave . . . given her freedom: reference is to the case treated of in Exodus 21:7-11
annotations.3: [23-25] Uncircumcised: by analogy with a newborn boy, the newly planted tree was considered impure until "circumcised" by offering to the Lord all the fruit it bore in the fourth year

Leviticus
Introduction
The name "Leviticus" was bestowed on the third book of the Pentateuch by the ancient Greek translators because a good part of this book consists of sacrificial and other ritual laws prescribed for the priests of the tribe of Levi. Continuing the legislation given by God to Moses at Mount Sinai, Leviticus is almost entirely legislative in character; the rare narrative portions are subordinate to the main legislative theme. Generally speaking, the laws contained in this book serve to teach the Israelites that they should always keep themselves in a state of legal purity, or external sanctity, as a sign of their intimate union with the Lord. Accordingly, the central idea of Leviticus is contained in its oft-repeated injunction: "You shall be holy, because I, the LORD, am holy." The main divisions of Leviticus are
I. Ritual of Sacrifices (Lev 1-7)
II. Ceremony of Ordination (Lev 8-10)
III. Laws regarding Legal Purity (Lev 11-16)
IV. Code of Legal Holiness (Lev 17-26)
V. Redemption of Offerings (Lev 27)

1.verse: The LORD said to Moses,

2.verse: "Take Aaron and his sons, together with the vestments, the anointing oil, the bullock for a sin offering, the two rams, and the basket of unleavened food.

3.verse: Then assemble the whole community at the entrance of the meeting tent."

4.verse: And Moses did as the LORD had commanded. When the community had assembled at the entrance of the meeting tent,

5.verse: Moses told them what the LORD had ordered to be done.

6.verse: Bringing forward Aaron and his sons, he first washed them with water.

7.verse: Then he put the tunic on Aaron, girded him with the sash, clothed him with the robe, placed the ephod on him, and girded him with the embroidered belt of the ephod, fastening it around him.

8.verse: He then set the breastpiece on him, with the Urim and Thummim in it,

9.verse: and put the miter on his head, attaching the gold plate, the sacred diadem, over the front of the miter, at his forehead, as the LORD had commanded him to do.

10.verse: Taking the anointing oil, Moses anointed and consecrated the Dwelling, with all that was in it.

11.verse: Then he sprinkled some of this oil seven times on the altar, and anointed the altar, with all its appurtenances, and the laver, with its base, thus consecrating them.

12.verse: He also poured some of the anointing oil on Aaron's head, thus consecrating him.

13.verse: Moses likewise brought forward Aaron's sons, clothed them with tunics, girded them with sashes, and put turbans on them, as the LORD had commanded him to do.

14.verse: When he had brought forward the bullock for a sin offering, Aaron and his sons laid their hands on its head.

15.verse: Then Moses slaughtered it, and taking some of its blood, with his finger he put it on the horns around the altar, thus purifying the altar. He also made atonement for the altar by pouring out the blood at its base when he consecrated it.

16.verse: Taking all the fat that was over the inner organs, as well as the lobe of the liver and the two kidneys with their fat, Moses burned them on the altar.

17.verse: The bullock, however, with its hide and flesh and offal he burned in the fire outside the camp, as the LORD had commanded him to do.

18.verse: He next brought forward the holocaust ram, and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on its head.

19.verse: When he had slaughtered it, Moses splashed its blood on all sides of the altar.

20.verse: After cutting up the ram into pieces, he burned the head, the cut-up pieces and the suet;

21.verse: then, having washed the inner organs and the shanks with water, he also burned these remaining parts of the ram on the altar as a holocaust, a sweet-smelling oblation to the LORD, as the LORD had commanded him to do.

22.verse: Then he brought forward the second ram, the ordination ram, and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on its head.

23.verse: When he had slaughtered it, Moses took some of its blood and put it on the tip of Aaron's right ear, on the thumb of his right hand, and on the big toe of his right foot.

24.verse: Moses had the sons of Aaron also come forward, and he put some of the blood on the tips of their right ears, on the thumbs of their right hands, and on the big toes of their right feet. The rest of the blood he splashed on the sides of the altar.

25.verse: He then took the fat: the fatty tail and all the fat over the inner organs, the lobe of the liver and the two kidneys with their fat, and likewise the right leg;

26.verse: from the basket of unleavened food that was set before the LORD he took one unleavened cake, one loaf of bread made with oil, and one wafer; these he placed on top of the portions of fat and the right leg.

27.verse: He then put all these things into the hands of Aaron and his sons, whom he had wave them as a wave offering before the LORD.

28.verse: When he had received them back, Moses burned them with the holocaust on the altar as the ordination offering, a sweet-smelling oblation to the LORD.

29.verse: He then took the breast and waved it as a wave offering before the LORD; this was Moses' own portion of the ordination ram. All this was in keeping with the LORD'S command to Moses.

30.verse: Taking some of the anointing oil and some of the blood that was on the altar, Moses sprinkled with it Aaron and his vestments, as well as his sons and their vestments, thus consecrating both Aaron and his vestments and his sons and their vestments.

31.verse: Finally, Moses said to Aaron and his sons, "Boil the flesh at the entrance of the meeting tent, and there eat it with the bread that is in the basket of the ordination offering, in keeping with the command I have received: 'Aaron and his sons shall eat of it.'

32.verse: What is left over of the flesh and the bread you shall burn up in the fire.

33.verse: Moreover, you are not to depart from the entrance of the meeting tent for seven days, until the days of your ordination are completed; for your ordination is to last for seven days.

34.verse: The LORD has commanded that what has been done today be done to make atonement for you.

35.verse: Hence you must remain at the entrance of the meeting tent day and night for seven days, carrying out the prescriptions of the LORD; otherwise, you shall die; for this is the command I have received."

36.verse: So Aaron and his sons did all that the LORD had commanded through Moses.

annotations.1: [1-9, 21] Though presented in the form of a narrative, this description of Aaron's ordination was intended to serve as a guide for all future ordinations
annotations.2: [2] The vestments, etc.: already described in Exodus 28-29
annotations.3: [8] The Urim and Thummim: see note on Exodus 28:30
annotations.4: [34] The sense is not quite clear. Either the verse gives merely the reason why God ordered this ceremony, or it contains God's command that the same ceremony be used in all future ordinations, or it decrees a repetition of the entire ceremony on each of the seven days. At least a sin offering for atonement was made on each of these days. Cf Exodus 29:29-36.

1.verse: The LORD said to Moses and Aaron,

2.verse: "Speak to the Israelites and tell them: Every man who is afflicted with a chronic flow from his private parts is thereby unclean.

3.verse: Such is his uncleanness from this flow that it makes no difference whether the flow drains off or is blocked up; his uncleanness remains.

4.verse: Any bed on which the man afflicted with the flow lies, is unclean, and any piece of furniture on which he sits, is unclean.

5.verse: Anyone who touches his bed shall wash his garments, bathe in water, and be unclean until evening.

6.verse: Whoever sits on a piece of furniture on which the afflicted man was sitting, shall wash his garments, bathe in water, and be unclean until evening.

7.verse: Whoever touches the body of the afflicted man shall wash his garments, bathe in water, and be unclean until evening.

8.verse: If the afflicted man spits on a clean man, the latter shall wash his garments, bathe in water, and be unclean until evening.

9.verse: Any saddle on which the afflicted man rides, is unclean.

10.verse: Whoever touches anything that was under him shall be unclean until evening; whoever lifts up any such thing shall wash his garments, bathe in water, and be unclean until evening.

11.verse: Anyone whom the afflicted man touches with unrinsed hands shall wash his garments, bathe in water, and be unclean until evening.

12.verse: Earthenware touched by the afflicted man shall be broken; and every wooden article shall be rinsed with water.

13.verse: "When a man who has been afflicted with a flow becomes free of his affliction, he shall wait seven days for his purification. Then he shall wash his garments and bathe his body in fresh water, and so he will be clean.

14.verse: On the eighth day he shall take two turtledoves or two pigeons, and going before the LORD, to the entrance of the meeting tent, he shall give them to the priest,

15.verse: who shall offer them up, the one as a sin offering and the other as a holocaust. Thus shall the priest make atonement before the LORD for the man's flow.

16.verse: "When a man has an emission of seed, he shall bathe his whole body in water and be unclean until evening.

17.verse: Any piece of cloth or leather with seed on it shall be washed with water and be unclean until evening.

18.verse: "If a man lies carnally with a woman, they shall both bathe in water and be unclean until evening.

19.verse: "When a woman has her menstrual flow, she shall be in a state of impurity for seven days. Anyone who touches her shall be unclean until evening.

20.verse: Anything on which she lies or sits during her impurity shall be unclean.

21.verse: Anyone who touches her bed shall wash his garments, bathe in water, and be unclean until evening.

22.verse: Whoever touches any article of furniture on which she was sitting, shall wash his garments, bathe in water, and be unclean until evening.

23.verse: But if she is on the bed or on the seat when he touches it, he shall be unclean until evening.

24.verse: If a man dares to lie with her, he contracts her impurity and shall be unclean for seven days; every bed on which he then lies also becomes unclean.

25.verse: "When a woman is afflicted with a flow of blood for several days outside her menstrual period, or when her flow continues beyond the ordinary period, as long as she suffers this unclean flow she shall be unclean, just as during her menstrual period.

26.verse: Any bed on which she lies during such a flow becomes unclean, as it would during her menstruation, and any article of furniture on which she sits becomes unclean just as during her menstruation.

27.verse: Anyone who touches them becomes unclean; he shall wash his garments, bathe in water, and be unclean until evening.

28.verse: "If she becomes freed from her affliction, she shall wait seven days, and only then is she to be purified.

29.verse: On the eighth day she shall take two turtledoves or two pigeons and bring them to the priest at the entrance of the meeting tent.

30.verse: The priest shall offer up one of them as a sin offering and the other as a holocaust. Thus shall the priest make atonement before the LORD for her unclean flow.

31.verse: "You shall warn the Israelites of their uncleanness, lest by defiling my Dwelling, which is in their midst, their uncleanness be the cause of their death.

32.verse: "This is the law for the man who is afflicted with a chronic flow, or who has an emission of seed, and thereby becomes unclean;

33.verse: as well as for the woman who has her menstrual period, or who is afflicted with a chronic flow; the law for male and female; and also for the man who lies with an unclean woman."
